topic.title: Restarting Freezer Backups after Reboot or Crash

section.p: Each time the freezer-scheduler is restarted on a node, which will occur any time a node is rebooted, the procedure documented below must be applied to the nodes that were rebooted.
If you do not do these steps for the rebooted nodes then no backups will be taken after the freezer-scheduler is restarted.

section.title: Create an Ansible Playbook to Clean the Freezer Jobs
section.p: These steps will show you how to create an ansible playbook that you can use to restart the backup jobs after a node reboot. This playbook will delete the old backup jobs and create fresh ones.

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager.

Create a file named _clean_freezer_jobs.yml with the contents below:
--- - hosts: FRE-AGN roles: - freezer-jobs tasks: - name: Clean old job templates become: yes file: path: /etc/freezer/scheduler/to_upload state: absent
- include: _freezer_manage_jobs.yml

section.title: Running the Ansible Playbook to Clean the Freezer Jobs
section.p: These steps will show you how to run the ansible playbook to clean the Freezer jobs.

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager.

Run the playbook.
If you want to run the playbook against all of the nodes in your environment, such as after an upgrade where all of your nodes are rebooted, use this command: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts _clean_freezer_jobs.yml
If you only rebooted specific nodes in your environment, but not all nodes, then you can specify a list of hosts like this: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts _clean_freezer_jobs.yml --limit <hostname> You can get a full list of hostnames in your environment by looking in your /etc/hosts file.

section.p: More information on the upstream bug is available here: https://bugs.launchpad.net/freezer/+bug/1546269
